entry.title: Re: Cross data locking
entry.content:
SAP authorization objects like K_CSKA (for cost elements) and K_CCTR (for cost centers) do not evaluate combinations. They check whether a user has access to a cost element or a cost center, but not whether they‚Äôre allowed to use a specific pair.

With some custom validation, you can meet this requirement. Explore BADI_FAGL_POSTING or BADI_K_KKB_AUTHORITY with which you can build logic to block specific combinations like 20321078 + 210020. Maintain the required combination like Cost Element 210020 / Cost Center 20321078 and User ID in TVARVC table. With the above BAdI, whenever user tries to create order or posting, system to check this table and if maintained, allow to proceed; else, throw an error. With this approach, at a later date, for some reasons, if you want to add a new entry or delete the existing entry, users can do on their own and no need for code change.

entry.title: Re: which is the difference between country key and repor...
entry.content:
In the context of fiscal representation, it's appropriate to use the fields as follows:

Country Key: This should reflect the parent company's country of registration‚Äîi.e., the country where the legal entity is based. It identifies the origin of the company involved in the transaction.

Reporting Country: This should indicate the country where the fiscal representative is registered and where the invoice will be reported for tax purposes. This is typically the country in which VAT or other indirect taxes are declared.

entry.title: Re: ST-PI Version Compatibility Between SAP Solution Mana...
entry.content:
Hello Rsnit and Luis,

Thanks very much for your input. I‚Äôve reviewed several SAP sources and found some relevant distinctions.

In one SAP blog, it‚Äôs stated that:

‚ÄúIt is highly recommended to keep software component ST-PI at the latest support package level (see SAP Note 539977) in Managed System as well as in the Solution Manager system. [‚Ä¶] The data collector changes provided in higher support packages are downward compatible e.g. a Solution Manager on ST 710 SP 12 can call a data collector in a managed system with ST-PI 2008_1_ SP 13.‚Äù*

This suggests that certain ST-PI functionalities, like data collectors, are designed to be downward compatible.

However, in SAP Note 69455 regarding ST-A/PI, it‚Äôs mentioned:

‚ÄúMay occur if the satellite system is on ST-A/PI >=01L but Solution Manager does not yet have the ST-SER 701_2008_2 [‚Ä¶] RTCCTOOL was enhanced [‚Ä¶] but the older Solution Manager release does not yet understand this.‚Äù

This indicates that other functionalities, such as RTCCTOOL integration with EarlyWatch Alert, may not be compatible if Solution Manager is on an older release.

Therefore, it seems there is no general SAP note that guarantees full downward compatibility across all ST-PI and ST-A/PI functionalities. While best practice remains to keep versions aligned, where this isn‚Äôt feasible, does SAP officially guarantee downward compatibility when the managed system is on a higher release than Solution Manager?

Best regards,
Silvio

entry.title: Re: Skipping popup messages in VA03 for Sales Order Incom...
entry.content:
SAP Note 1459252 suggests this only as a workaround, not a standard solution. It‚Äôs not part of core functionality, so it should be treated as a last resort.

If the goal is to reduce user frustration without compromising data integrity:

  • First, analyze which fields are causing the incompletion logs.
  • Then, adjust the incompletion procedure to remove non-critical fields.
  • Use BAdIs or user exits to suppress popups for completed orders.
  • Only consider deleting from VBUV if all else fails; and always back up the data first.

entry.title: Re: The Value of SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) in The Context of Business Steering
entry.content:
Hi @thomaselit,

Great feedback and I will try to address it:

Besides the mentioned (and ‚Äúexcluded‚Äù) components SAP BDC is also introducing new services. Such as:

  1. Curated SaaS Data products
  2. Intelligent Apps
  3. SAP Databricks (for AI/ML) use cases

We are adding business content  - data models, semantics and solutions ‚Äì intelligent apps (such as Working Capital, People Intelligence and more to come) to tackle the volatility of todays market. We are doing this in true SaaS manner (‚Äúplug & play‚Äù), so that our customers don‚Äôt have to reinvent the wheel when it comes to data integration, modelling, preserving business rules & semantics from source systems, etc. The platform is fully integrated with our AI services (SAP AI Hub), that will help to introduce new use cases when it comes to supporting the business steering (for example AI agent to provide additional insights about our business performance in the context of overall market performance, AI agent for risk analysis ‚Äì going towards the prescriptive analytics by providing suggestions, etc). We are also enabling advanced AI/ML use cases with SAP Databricks without the replication (delta share/zero copy) - > allowing (near) real time insights and more‚Ä¶

In case you need more support with presenting/selling the SAP BDC offering to your customer(s) please get in touch with our local SAP office to get some additional support (alternatively feel free to send me a message and we can connect you to the right people in your region).

entry.title: Re: ST-PI Version Compatibility Between SAP Solution Mana...
entry.content:
Hello Silvio,

The comment  you refer:

Q14: "Last run of report RTCCTOOL" in EWAlert too old
A14: May occur if the satellite system is on ST-A/PI >=01L but Solution Manager does not yet have the ST-SER 701_2008_2 (both as of December 2008). RTCCTOOL was enhanced as of ST-A/PI 01L to deliver the full recommendations to the EWAlert, but the older Solution Manager release does not yet understand this.
As a workaround run report RTCCTOOL from Tx SE38 and choose Goto->Old RTCCTOOL from the menu. This runs the old tool, which should now also return green status lights for everything that's up to date. The next EWA ( with your current ST-SER) takes this info from the old tool into account.
As a permanent solution, update your Solution Manager to EhP1 (ST 400 SP18, ST-SER 701_2008_2).

It talks about 2008 version which probably referred to SAP Solution Manager 7.0 or 7.1 version. 
There shouldn't be such situation right now, so best practice is to check with RTCCTOOL which is the latest available version to implement on corresponding system. 

Regards,

Luis Salazar

entry.content:
@tsuuuu 

A simple js code in on initialization event of the page can get you that.

Create a script variable of type string called CurrentDate ( can name it as per your choice)

Put the below code in the  on initialization event of the page

var currentDate = new Date(Date.now()); //fetch current date

if(currentDate.getMonth()+1<10) // +1 as js month index at 0
{
	CurrentDate =currentDate.getFullYear().toString()+"/"+ "0"+ (currentDate.getMonth() + 1).toString();
}
	else
		{
			CurrentDate =currentDate.getFullYear().toString()+"/"+ "0"+ (currentDate.getMonth() + 1).toString();
		}

Finally bind the dynamic text with script variable CurrentDate

Output:

 

Hope this helps !!

entry.title: Re: Setting up default Variant in ME28
entry.content:
The Scope of List field in ME28 is not variant-sensitive, meaning it doesn't retain the value from your saved variant when you reopen the transaction. Even if you save a variant with "BEST" selected, ME28 will default back to "ALV" unless additional steps are taken.

One option which you can explore is create a Custom Transaction (ZME28) via SE93 with your saved variant of ME28. In the setup, specify the variant where "BEST" is selected. This way, users launch ZME28 and get the desired Scope of List by default. But this is worth only

  • if ME28 is used daily by multiple users, and everyone has to manually switch the Scope of List to "BEST" each time, that‚Äôs a lot of wasted clicks.
  • If users consistently forget to change the Scope of List, leading to incorrect or incomplete release processing.
  • A custom transaction simplifies onboarding‚Äîusers just launch ZME28 and get the correct setup instantly.

The other option is to have an user parameter transaction which can be done via SE93 through which you can create a new tcode ZME28_BEST. Select "Transaction with parameters (parameter transaction)". In the transaction field, set ME28. Set default parameters by adding the following:

  • D_SREPOVARI-REPORT = RM06EF00 (the program behind ME28)
  • D_SREPOVARI-VARIANT = your saved variant name (e.g., BEST_SCOPE)

These parameters ensure ME28 loads with your desired variant.

entry.title: Enhanced Tax Calculation in the Upload Customer Open Items App
entry.content:
Starting from SAP S/4HANA Cloud 2508,  a new field, Tax Amount (TAXAMOUNTINTRANSCRCY), has been added to the Header Data section of the upload template for the Upload Customer Open Items app.

Depending on the value in this field, the system calculates taxes differently:

  • If you leave the field empty or set the field value to zero, the system calculates the tax amount automatically based on the tax code you specified during checking and posting.
  • If you enter a tax amount in this field, the system uses the amount you specified manually for checking and posting.
The Tax Amount field is hidden by default in the template. To make it visible, unhide the columns at the end of the Header Data section.
Field Technical NameField Name
TAXAMOUNTINTRANSCRCYTax Amount

Depending on the value in this field, the system calculates taxes differently:
If you leave the field empty or set the field value to zero, the system calculates the tax amount automatically based on the tax code you specified in the Tax Code (2) field during checking and posting.

If you enter a tax amount, the system uses the amount you specified manually for checking and posting.
 
After uploading an open item back to the app, you can view the Tax Amount field in the Details section of the open item details page and edit the field value as needed.
 
 
Note

You cannot enter a tax amount manually at the G/L account item level. When you enter a tax amount for an open item in the header and use different tax codes in its G/L account items, the system automatically distributes the tax amount among the various tax codes during checking and posting.

entry.title: How to use latest QUnit and sinon to test your SAPUI5 applications
entry.content:
Are you a SAPUI5 developer who loves writing unit tests but feels held back by the outdated versions of sinon and qunit bundled with the framework? You're not alone.

For convenience, the SAPUI5 framework ships with its own versions of these popular testing libraries, available directly from the UI5 CDN. The challenge, however, is that these bundled versions are outdated. The SAPUI5 CDN supplies sinon v4 at latest, which is more than 7 years old, while version 21 is already available. As there are no plans to update the version available in the CDN (see https://github.com/UI5/openui5/issues/3204), we developers have to integrate it by ourselves to benefit from sinon's and qunit's latest features. That is some cumbersome work, esp. if every project / developer needs to figure out the 'right' way to do it.

In this post, we'll walk you through a setup that allows you to integrate the latest versions of sinon and qunit into your SAPUI5 project, unlocking its latest features, superior type-safety, and a much-improved developer experience. Let's get started!

There are 2 possibilities to approach this depending on your UI5 version (see feat: Use Test Starter ¬∑ ui5-community/generator-ui5-ts-app)
1. UI5 version >= 1.124: using test starter setup
2. UI5 version < 1.124: using traditional test suite & test page setup

To guide you through the steps, we will use the easy-ui5 generator to generate a TypeScript application (I can strongly recommend this tool). You can install it via the following command (see also generator-easy-ui5 - npm)

npm install -g yo generator-easy-ui5

Additionally, we need to use the middleware ui5-tooling-modules-middleware of the UI5 Tooling ecosystem. This middleware enables you to use NPM package names for AMD-like dependencies. It captures the requests to the path /resources/ and checks whether a dependency or devDependency is included with the identical name as the requested resource. If this is the case, it will serve this dependency from your installed node_modules and return it as a AMD-like dependency. This enables you to easily utilise third-party packages in your UI5 applications.

Using UI5 >= 1.124

We create our new application via the following command:

yo easy-ui5 ts-app

For the sample the namespace com.testing.unit is used. Now, make sure to choose a version greater than or equals 1.124.0. Answer the remaining questions according to your preferences.

Afterwards, add qunit and sinon to devDependencies:

npm install --save-dev sinon @types/sinon qunit @types/qunit

If not already present, add also the latest version of ui5-tooling-modules-middleware  to the devDependencies:

npm install ui5-tooling-modules --save-dev -rte

By using the flag -rte or --register-tooling-extension the module adds its configuration automatically to the default UI5 yaml files. If you want to add it to other specific files, you can mention them after the flag: -rte ui5.yaml,ui5-workspace.yaml. Please make sure that the ui5-coverage.yaml is configured as follows. This UI5 yaml file is used to execute your tests. You must add the middleware ui5-tooling-modules-middleware to the server serving the application. Add this middleware to the section server/customMiddleware as shown below. The only custom configuration option we use, is debug: verbose to get a more detailed logging output in case of errors. Then, we can easily see whether a dependency was added and served or ignored. The transpiling of your TypeScript code must be executed after the middleware as the dependencies could potentially also contain TypeScript code.

...
server:
  customMiddleware:
	- name: ui5-tooling-modules-middleware
      afterMiddleware: compression
      configuration:
        debug: verbose
    - name: ui5-tooling-transpile-middleware
      afterMiddleware: ui5-tooling-modules-middleware
      configuration:
        targetBrowsers: "defaults and supports async-functions"
        debug: true
        transpileDependencies: true
        babelConfig:
          sourceMaps: true
          ignore:
            - "**/*.d.ts"
          presets:
            - - "@babel/preset-env"
              - targets: defaults
            - - transform-ui5
            - "@babel/preset-typescript"
          plugins:
            - istanbul

Now, you get a new test setup using the test starter setup. Instead of the traditional test suite and test pages for unit and integration test setup, you get a testsuite.qunit.ts with central configuration options and for the unit and integration tests a source file (unitTests.qunit.ts / opaTests.qunit.ts) where you just import your test cases. In the testsuite.qunit.ts we can configure the used versions for qunit and sinon. By default, only the versions available in the CDN can be used. Luckily, you can add custom versions to the versions map and consume them via ui5-tooling-modules-middleware. Therefore, you have to add the property versions to the qunit and sinon object and insert your version of the libraries to be used.
Additionally, for qunit you have to define the module itself and the path to the css file so that you get the tests page styled as you are used to. For sinon, you have to define the module and the bridge which helps qunit to communicate with sinon. The value of these properties is the path used to load the source files. They are automatically loaded from the /resources/ path. Therefore, this part must not be contained in the property value. The default bridge from SAPUI5 core can be reused, even with the latest version of sinon. Now, you just have to specify the version. This must be identical to the version number you just maintained in the property versions.

Then, the result shall look like this:

export default {
	name: "QUnit test suite for the UI5 Application: com.testing.unit",
	defaults: {
		page: "ui5://test-resources/com/testing/unit/Test.qunit.html?testsuite={suite}&test={name}",
		qunit: {
			version: "2.24.1",
			versions: {
				"2.24.1": {
					module: "qunit",
					css: "qunit/qunit/qunit.css",
				},
			},
		},
		sinon: {
			version: "21.0.0",
			versions: {
				"21.0.0": {
					module: "sinon",
					bridge: "sap/ui/qunit/sinon-qunit-bridge",
				},
			},
		},
		ui5: {
			language: "EN",
			theme: "sap_horizon",
		},
		coverage: {
			only: "com/testing/unit/",
			never: "test-resources/com/testing/unit/",
		},
		loader: {
			paths: {
				"com/testing/unit": "../",
			},
			map: {
				"*": {
					qunit: null,
					sinon: null,
				},
			},
		},
	},
	tests: {
		"unit/unitTests": {
			title: "Unit tests for com.testing.unit",
		},
		"integration/opaTests": {
			title: "Integration tests for com.testing.unit",
		},
	},
};

Additionally, you have to overwrite SAPUI5's module loader so that qunit and sinon won't be loaded from the CDN. Otherwise, every import of sinon and qunit would be redirected to sap/ui/thirdparty/<sinon/qunit>. Therefore, you have to adapt the property defaults/loader/map/*. In there, set the value null for qunit and sinon. Then, our custom mapping applies and the source files are requested from our own application. The middleware ui5-tooling-modules-middleware will recognise that a local dependency is requested, package it as a SAPUI5 module and return it to the running application.

In short you have to do 3 things:
- Maintain the version to be used
- Add your custom version to the versions map
- Overwrite SAPUI5's default module loader to not load sinon and qunit from the CDN

Now, you can continue with the section Verify your setup.

Using UI5 < 1.124

If you are not able to use the latest version, you have to rely on the traditional suite and test page setup like we UI5 developers are used to. Nevertheless, the same as above is possible with this approach.

We create our new application via the following command:

yo easy-ui5 ts-app

For the sample the namespace com.testing.unit is used. Now make sure to choose a version lower than 1.124.0. Answer the remaining questions according to your preferences.

Afterwards, add qunit and sinon to devDependencies:

npm install --save-dev sinon @types/sinon qunit @types/qunit

If not already present, add also the latest version of ui5-tooling-modules-middleware to the devDependencies:

npm install ui5-tooling-modules --save-dev -rte

By using the flag -rte or --register-tooling-extension the module adds its configuration automatically to the default UI5 yaml files. If you want to add it to other specific files, you can mention them after the flag: -rte ui5.yaml,ui5-workspace.yaml. Please make sure that the ui5-coverage.yaml is configured as described above:

...
server:
  customMiddleware:
	- name: ui5-tooling-modules-middleware
      afterMiddleware: compression
      configuration:
        debug: verbose
    - name: ui5-tooling-transpile-middleware
      afterMiddleware: ui5-tooling-modules-middleware
      configuration:
        targetBrowsers: "defaults and supports async-functions"
        debug: true
        transpileDependencies: true
        babelConfig:
          sourceMaps: true
          ignore:
            - "**/*.d.ts"
          presets:
            - - "@babel/preset-env"
              - targets: defaults
            - - transform-ui5
            - "@babel/preset-typescript"
          plugins:
            - istanbul

Now, please adapt your test/unit/unitTests.qunit.html to overwrite SAP's default module loader and ensure that sinon and qunit are loaded form the local resources.

<!doctype html>
<html>
  <head>
    <title>Applicationportal - Unit Tests</title>
    <meta charset="utf-8" />

    <script
      id="sap-ui-bootstrap"
      src="/resources/sap-ui-core.js"
      data-sap-ui-resourceroots='{
		  "aa.foerdermittelportal.applicationportal.ui": "../../"
	  }'
      data-sap-ui-async="false"
    ></script>

    <!-- Load sinon and qunit before stylesheet to ensure that they are loaded when test execution starts by requiring unitTests.qunit.js -->
    <script src="/resources/sinon.js"></script>
    <script src="/resources/qunit.js"></script>
    <!-- Overwrite default mapping, otherwise every import of sinon and qunit is redirected to sap/ui/thirdparty/<sinon/qunit> by ui5loader -->
    <script>
      sap.ui.loader.config({
        map: {
          "*": {
            qunit: null,
            sinon: null,
          },
        },
      });
    </script>

    <link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="/resources/qunit/qunit/qunit.css" />

    <script src="unitTests.qunit.js"></script>
  </head>
  <body>
    <div id="qunit"></div>
    <div id="qunit-fixture"></div>
  </body>
</html>

Now, you can continue with the section Verify your setup.

Verify your setup

Now, we will add a unit test to showcase that the latest version of sinon is used. Therefore, we first add a new method to the Main.controller.ts:

import MessageBox from "sap/m/MessageBox";
import BaseController from "./BaseController";
import JSONModel from "sap/ui/model/json/JSONModel";

/**
 *  com.testing.unit.controller
 */
export default class Main extends BaseController {
	public sayHello(): void {
		MessageBox.show("Hello World!");
	}

	public getGreeting(): string {
		const model = this.getModel("greeting") as JSONModel;

		return model.getProperty("/greeting") as string;
	}
}

To test the new method, add the following test, to your webapp/test/unit/controller/Main.qunit.ts:

import Main from "com/testing/unit/controller/Main.controller";
import JSONModel from "sap/ui/model/json/JSONModel";
import * as sinon from "sinon";

type TestContext = {
	controller: Main;
	stubbedJSONModel: sinon.SinonStubbedInstance<JSONModel>;
};

QUnit.module("Sample Main controller test", {
	beforeEach(this: TestContext) {
		this.stubbedJSONModel = sinon.createStubInstance(JSONModel);
		this.controller = new Main("test");
	},

	afterEach(this: TestContext) {
		sinon.restore();
	},
});

QUnit.test("sinon v21 is used", function (this: TestContext, assert) {
	const getModelStub = sinon.stub(this.controller, "getModel");
	getModelStub.withArgs("greeting").returns(this.stubbedJSONModel);

	this.stubbedJSONModel.getProperty.returns("Hello from sinon v21!");

	this.controller.getGreeting();

	assert.strictEqual(this.controller.getGreeting(), "Hello from sinon v21!");

	// -expect-error sinon fakeXMLHttpRequest is removed with sinon v20
	assert.strictEqual(undefined, sinon.fakeXMLHttpRequest);
});

If you get an error regarding the import of sinon, adapt your tsconfig.json to allow allowSyntheticDefaultImports:

{
	compilerOptions: {
		...
		"allowSyntheticDefaultImports": true,
		...
	}
}

In short, we did 2 things:
- Imported sinon to be able to write assertions,
- Added the tests which verifies that we are using the latest version of sinon by ensuring that methods which are no longer available in v21 are undefined.

Now you can start your application using the ui5-coverage.yaml:

npm run start-coverage

Open the test page in your browser and open also the network tab of your developer tools:

  • If you are using UI5 >= 1.124: http://localhost:8080/test/Test.qunit.html?testsuite=test-resources/com/testing/unit/testsuite.qunit&test=unit/unitTests 
  • If you are using UI5 < 1.124: http://localhost:8080/test/unit/unitTests.qunit.html 

Once the tests are executed, you can verify the sources returned for sinon and qunit. You will see, that the configured versions are loaded and used:

And the same for qunit:

 And also in your server's logs:

The first warning regarding the package sinon can be ignored (see orange marked section in the logs). sinon is only used for our tests and therefore included as a devDependency. Therefore, the warning will arise but in a deployed we won't need this dependency. This means we are fine with the dynamic inclusion of sinon into our bundle (see red marked section in the logs).

Conclusion

By moving away from the default bundled libraries and integrating your own dependencies, you've now unlocked the full potential of modern testing in your SAPUI5 application. To make your journey as smooth as possible, the complete sample project is available on GitHub: ui5-unit-testing-latest-qunit-sinon  
Happy testing!
If you have any questions or found this guide helpful, feel free to leave a comment below. If you are interested in the setup of the coverage reporting for UI5 applications, we may cover this in a part 2 in the future.

entry.title: SAC 2025 Q3 QRC Optimized Story API - Is there a change in DataSource.getMeasures() behavior?
entry.content:
Hello, I am using SAC Analytics Cloud and utilize scripts to enhance the functionality of optimized stories.  Last week we received latest quarterly update (2025 Q3 QRC, version 2025.14.8).  After the update, I noticed the behavior of DataSource.getMeasures() has changed. 

The API Reference says this method "Returns all measures of the data source" and this was exactly the behavior before.  Now it only returns the first 200 measures, just like the default behavior of DataSource.getMembers().  This causes problem for my existing stories because our queries usually contain 200+ measures (model-defined measures + story calculations). 
To make it worse, now the story calculations are indexed after model-defined measures (before the update: calculations first), so calculations are almost never included in getMeasures() method.

Is this an intended change?  Shall I modify the scripts in stories now, or wait for a fix in next versions? Thanks.

entry.title: Elevate Your Promotion Strategy: Baseline Management with SAP Revenue Growth Management
entry.content:
1. The Blind Spot: How Baseline Data Impacts KAM Success

For Key Account Managers, managing promotional success often starts with understanding the sales baseline ‚Äî the steady sales volume without promotions. Without a clear baseline, measuring promotional lift and trade spend ROI can feel like groping around looking for a lightswitch in the dark. Manual data handling, inconsistent baselines across systems, and lack of flexibility to reflect market changes can turn promotion planning into a high-stakes gamble.

 

2. SAP Revenue Growth Management: A Foundation for Data-Driven Revenue Planning

SAP Revenue Growth Management (RGM) addresses the challenges above. Designed for consumer products companies, our solution empowers KAMs with intuitive, integrated, and flexible baseline management tools ‚Äî whether you manage key accounts at a major corporation or lead revenue growth at a midsize company.

For more information on our current capabilities, see An Overview of SAP Revenue Growth Management.

 

3. Baseline in Action: Three Essentials Shaping Smarter Account Planning

Baseline isn‚Äôt just a number‚Äîit‚Äôs the foundation for every strategic decision a KAM makes. Among the many strengths of SAP Revenue Growth Management, the Baseline feature stands out as the backbone. Here‚Äôs how its three core strengths put you in control:

3.1. Baseline Maintenance via Excel‚Äî Seamlessly Fits KAM Workflow

For teams accustomed to spreadsheets, SAP Revenue Growth Management meets you where you are.

  • Matching Existing Processes

Many KAMs at small and medium enterprises traditionally manage revenue and baseline data in Excel. SAP Revenue Growth Management respects this workflow by enabling KAMs to download Excel templates, fill in baseline volumes offline, and then upload the completed files back into the system.

  • Minimal Training, Maximum Adoption

KAMs can leverage familiar spreadsheet skills to manage baselines without learning new systems, accelerating adoption and ensuring data quality.

 

This approach is especially effective for small-to-medium companies whose teams may not have supply chain and demand planning tools like SAP Integrated Business Planning (IBP) to forecast and manage sell-in baselines, or other tools that produce consumption-based demand forecasts from syndicated sell-out data. The baseline upload and building blocks in SAP Revenue Growth Management allow KAMs to efficiently devise and handle a forecasted sell-in baseline without waiting for centralized teams.

 

3.2. Integrating with External Demand Planning System via Open API ‚Äî Tailored for Large Enterprises

Ideal for larger consumer products companies with centralized demand planning systems and tools.

  • Unified Baseline Integration Across Multiple Sources and Systems

In large companies, a baseline forecast can come from a demand planning tool, such as SAP Integrated Business Planning (IBP) to forecast sell-in baselines, or a consumption-based forecast from historical sell-out data ‚Äì with data suitably transformed to utilize the Baseline Volume API of SAP Revenue Growth Management. This approach ensures that baseline data stays current and aligned across systems by week by SKU, significantly reducing manual workload while meeting customers where they are, regardless of the baseline source.

  • Support Role-Based Access and Governance

Planned as a future enhancement, this feature will allow demand planners to centrally edit baselines while KAMs view baselines and work with given numbers to plan promotions and boost revenue. Such organizations can maintain clear data ownership and restrict baseline editing to authorized roles (e.g., demand planners), aligning well with corporate compliance while freeing KAMs to focus on customer strategy.

 

This integration empowers demand planning teams to stay agile in fast-changing markets, while ensuring adherence to corporate data governance.

 

3.3. Baseline Building Blocks: Adapt to Market Realities with Agility

For large enterprises leveraging API integrations, baseline updates are typically centralized with demand planners. Meanwhile, for growing companies, when Excel can‚Äôt keep pace with change, the ability for KAM‚Äôs to use their account knowledge to adjust and tweak baselines on the fly is necessary.

  • Configurable Baseline Building Blocks for Market Drivers

Adjustment factors like retailers' store openings, renovations, and seasonality can influence sales baseline independently of promotions. In the future, baseline building blocks will become configurable through central configuration managed by admins. Companies will be able to define these market drivers based on their business models and governance requirements. This empowers KAMs to apply tailored, business-driven adjustments at flexible time granularities‚Äîweekly, monthly, or quarterly views‚Äîensuring agile baseline management aligned with real market conditions within SAP Revenue Growth Management.

  • Visual Editing by Product Category and Time Period

KAMs can quickly update baselines for specific product categories and time periods without re-uploading entire datasets‚Äîchanges are automatically and reasonably distributed to daily levels, reflecting real business scenarios where promotions are typically planned daily.

 

This feature bridges the gap between static data and fluid market conditions, equipping KAMs to respond promptly with minimal overhead.

 

4. Co-Innovation: Put Your Baseline to Work

Baseline management lays the groundwork for smarter account planning and precise promotion ROI. In SAP Revenue Growth Management‚Äôs embedded analytics feature, the volume and revenue dashboards identify baseline and uplift, providing reporting and visualization of baseline versus uplift.

To stay ahead in a dynamic market, your insights and feedback are invaluable.

If you face challenges such as:

  • Needing more flexible, in-application baseline editing capabilities
  • Wanting streamlined workflows for baseline adjustment and governance
  • Handling the impacts of baseline changes on promotions

Join our co-innovation program to influence planned enhancements, including:

  • In-app baseline editing for real-time updates without Excel
  • Centralized baseline configuration and role-based access controls
  • Enhanced handling of baseline changes and the effects on promotions

Whether you represent a growing company or a global enterprise, your participation will help us enhance the Baseline in SAP Revenue Growth Management. Contact RGM_Engage@sap.com to collaborate and build the next generation of baseline and account planning efficiencies.

More Information

Documentation on SAP Help Portal

Topic Page for SAP Revenue Growth Management

  • Unlocking Trade Spend Control Efficiency with Funds Management in SAP Revenue Growth Management
  • Decoding Promotional Success: Embedded Analytics in SAP Revenue Growth Management
  • Introducing Calendar View in SAP Revenue Growth Management: A Visual Leap for Strategic Planning
  • Consolidating Customer Planning: Unleash Growth with SAP Revenue Growth Management‚Äôs Account Plan
  • Elevate Your Promotion Strategy: Baseline Management with SAP Revenue Growth Management

entry.title: Re: Access CDS Objects Exposed as SQL Services Using Microsoft SQL Server
entry.content:
Hi Roberto,
Unfortunately the connection string parameter DecFloatSqlType=WVarchar requires a ABAP Basis version 9.14(Cloud) or 8.16(OnPrem) or higher. On lower backend versions the driver will ignore this parameter and continue to the use the driver specific ODBC type SQL_DECFLOAT for decimal floating point numbers. Your SAP basis version is 7.57.

In any case those decimal floating point numbers present a problem for MicroSoft applications like Excel or MS SQL since they do not support a numeric type with the same value range. DecFloatSqlType=WVarchar is also just a workaround to avoid the driver specific type and in this case the numbers are retrieved as strings. Currently only HANA and DB2 have native support for decimal floating point types and map those types correctly in their federation features.

Casting to DOUBLE is possible but not recommended because you get exactly the rounding problems you want to avoid by using a decimal floating point type. For currency values this may not be suitable. So if you want to add explicit casts for currency values it may be better to cast to a fixed point decimal type.
Regards
                   Frank

SQL> select cast (1.05 as double) DOUB, CAST(1.05 AS DECIMAL) D34N, CAST(1.05 AS DECIMAL(10,2) ) DEC102 from SYS.DUMMY
+----------------------------------------+-------------------------------------------+-------------+

| DOUB | D34N | DEC102 |

+----------------------------------------+-------------------------------------------+-------------+

| 1.0500000000000000444089209850063 | 1.05 | 1.05 |
+----------------------------------------+-------------------------------------------+-------------+

entry.title: Re: ST-PI Version Compatibility Between SAP Solution Mana...
entry.content:
Hello Silvio,
There is no official statement of SAP Guarantees low ST-PI version comparing Solution Manager and Managed System. By running low ST-PI or ST/A-PI version , you accept code corrections delivered for corresponding data collectors are not applied, and therefore applications like System Monitoring might be affected, not being able to collect data or providing wrong data.

Regards,

Luis Salazar

entry.title: Re: SII tip for Spain #2: Reuse <NumSerieFacturaEmisor> in case of de-registered invoices
entry.content:
Hi

As I mentioned, the Tax Agency does not accept two invoices (communication types A0) with the same combination of <NIF><NumSerieFacturaEmisor><FechaExpedicionFacturaEmisor> , even if the first one was cancelled.

However, the tax agency does accept a modification  (communication type A1) of an existing combination of <NIF><NumSerieFacturaEmisor><FechaExpedicionFacturaEmisor>  provided it was already posted. How to achieve the SII to run a modification, is described as you mention (Note 2558684 - SII error 3000 from AT after deregistered vendor invoice - SAP for Me).

I will adjust the post with this information. Thanks for the feedback.

Regards

Francisco.

entry.title: Multi-Origin Service Testing and Troubleshooting in SAP Gateway
entry.content:
In this blog, I‚Äôll walk you through:

  • How to test multi-origin services in SAP Gateway

  • How to pass the correct system alias in requests

  • How to debug and troubleshoot common issues

  • Real examples and outputs

1. Quick Refresher: What‚Äôs Multi-Origin in SAP Gateway?

Multi-origin lets you use a single OData service definition and pull data from multiple backend systems.
Which backend you hit is controlled by the System Alias in Gateway and selected by passing $system in the request.

Example:

/sap/opu/odata/SAP/ZSALES_ORDER_SRV/$metadata?$system=ERPCLNT100

Here, ERPCLNT100 is the system alias defined in /IWFND/MAINT_SERVICE.

2. How I Test Multi-Origin OData Services

Step 1 ‚Äì Check the Aliases First

Before sending any request, I always check if the right aliases are even there.
T-Code: /IWFND/MAINT_SERVICE ‚Üí search for your service ‚Üí open System Aliases tab.

Example setup:

If the alias isn‚Äôt listed here, $system won‚Äôt work ‚Äî no matter how perfect your URL looks.Service Name Version System Alias Default

If the alias isn‚Äôt listed here, $system won‚Äôt work ‚Äî no matter how perfect your URL looks.

Step 2 ‚Äì Use the Gateway Client

T-Code: /IWFND/GW_CLIENT
Service URL example:

/sap/opu/odata/SAP/ZSALES_ORDER_SRV/SalesOrders?$top=5&$system=S4HCLNT200

After execution, if the data comes from the intended backend, you‚Äôre good.
Sample JSON snippet from my test:

{
  "d": {
    "results": [
      {
        "SalesOrder": "50001234",
        "CreatedBy": "USER1",
        "SalesOrg": "1000"
      }
    ]
  }
}

Step 3 ‚Äì Test Outside SAP

If the service is active, you can also test from a browser or Postman:

https://<gateway_host>:<port>/sap/opu/odata/SAP/ZSALES_ORDER_SRV/SalesOrders?$system=ERPCLNT100

This is handy when you want to share the request with someone in another team.

3. Troubleshooting ‚Äì Real Cases I‚Äôve Faced

Case 1 ‚Äì $system Ignored

  • Symptom: No matter what you pass, data always comes from the default system.

  • Fix: Ensure both aliases are active and $system exactly matches the alias name (not the RFC destination name).

Case 2 ‚Äì 500 Internal Server Error

  • I‚Äôve hit this when the RFC destination wasn‚Äôt configured in SM59 or the backend service wasn‚Äôt active.

  • Fix: Activate the service in /IWBEP/REG_SERVICE in the backend and test the RFC destination.

Case 3 ‚Äì 403 Forbidden

  • Happens when the user has Gateway access but no backend role.

  • Fix: Assign the required /IWBEP/ authorizations in the backend.

4. Debugging Multi-Origin Requests

Option 1 ‚Äì Gateway Side
T-Code: /IWFND/TRACES ‚Üí enable trace ‚Üí run your request ‚Üí check ‚ÄúSystem Alias Used‚Äù.

Sample trace output:

System Alias: S4HCLNT200
Backend RFC: SAP_S4H_200
Execution Time: 512 ms

Option 2 ‚Äì Backend Side
Set an external breakpoint in your *_DPC_EXT class method in SE80/SE24.
When you call the service with $system, the debugger will trigger in the correct backend if the routing is working.

5. My Go-To Best Practices

  • Always test each alias separately before enabling multi-origin in production.

  • Keep alias names intuitive and consistent across landscapes.

  • Use Postman collections for each alias to speed up re-testing.

  • Keep an eye on performance ‚Äî I‚Äôve seen the same service respond in 200 ms from one backend and 3 seconds from another.

Conclusion:

Testing and Troubleshooting multi-origin in OData is not just about passing $system in the URL ‚Äî it‚Äôs about ensuring the entire connection chain works, from alias mapping to backend service activation. By combining SAP Gateway tools like /IWFND/GW_CLIENT, /IWFND/TRACES, and backend debugging, you can quickly pinpoint and resolve issue.

entry.title: Cookbook - SAP Query usage statistics
entry.content:
From the context of the migration of ECC to the S4 HANA, the relevance of query reduction may become more of a necessity rather than just a nice-to-have discipline. The reason pertains to the special nature of queries, as they are ‚Äògenerated code‚Äô and not similar to regular custom code. As a whole, making ECC queries compatible with S4 may be a daunting task. Therefore, dedicated efforts will be needed to analyze the usage data of queries so that only the required ones migrate into S4 HANA and not the entire list of queries, as many of them are seldom used or may no longer be needed. The usage will provide quantitative information for IT and business to make an informed decision to determine the queries required for the S4 HANA system.

However, there is no straightforward way to calculate query usage statistics. In this write-up, we will attempt to arrive at a process to calculate the usage statistics of the SAP query.

Step 1: Create a List of Queries

  • Run transaction SQ02: Click on ‚ÄòGo To‚Äô √† Select ‚ÄòQuery Directory‚Äô √† and run wide open

Step 2: Extract raw data for query usage

  • Run transaction SCMON and select ‚ÄòDisplay data.‚Äô

This write-up assumed that there are three ways SAP Query can be called:

  • Direct query call using SQ01
  • Query running in Batch jobs
  • Query called through custom transactions

Usage Data Collection

  • Get usage data for direct call using SQ01 from SCMON using ‚ÄòCalling Request Entry Point‚Äô as Type = ‚ÄòT‚Äô and Name = ‚ÄòSQ01‚Äô (see below)

Next screen

Key steps to be followed:

  • Downloaded the list for ‚ÄòSubmitted Report‚Äô (or DELETE other Request type rows from downloaded report so that we ONLY get ‚ÄòSubmitted Report‚Äô in resultant Excel)
  • Concatenate User Group & Query name in a NEW column before Num of Calls column (for easier VLOOKUP later)
  • Get usage data for batch call using jobs from SCMON using ‚ÄòCalling Request Entry Point‚Äô as Type = ‚ÄòB‚Äô and Name = ‚ÄòAQIC*‚Äô (see below)

In the next screen, filter only Procurement Type as ‚ÄòSSEL‚Äô (as we only want to know the start of selection)

  • Get usage data for custom transaction call from SCMON using ‚ÄòCalling Request Entry Point‚Äô as Type = ‚ÄòT‚Äô and Name = ‚Äòall custom tcode‚Äô that calls a SAP query at execution. (see below)

In the output, filter only records with ‚ÄòProc Type‚Äô as SSEL.

Once we extract raw data, the remaining portion of the work pertains to connecting data from different files and deriving intelligence on collective usage/calls of respective queries (hint: use Mid & VLOOKUP functions in Excel).

Ultimately, sum up all usages to get the final usage (sample output)

Conclusion:

This write has considered one of the possible approaches to simplistically arrive at the usage data for SAP queries, several which tend to grow significantly with the complexity of business processes and user requirements. For system migration, specifically in the context of S4 HANA conversion from ECC, reduction of redundant queries can pay substantial dividend.

entry.title: How to Clean Up Billing Plan Settlement Rules for Your Service Contracts
entry.content:
Introduction

If you're using service contracts, especially the periodic billing plans, in your business, it's important to ensure that you choose correct settlement rules for the system to generate billing request lines automatically. The rules shown in the Manage Service Contracts app come from the date rules that your configuration experts have set up for the  date profile used for service contracts in your configuration environment. According to current technical design, all the date rules assigned to the date profile of service contracts appear as options, no matter whether they're relevant or not. This is confusing.

In this blog, we're going to explain how to clean up those date rule options for periodic billing plans. With simple settings, only the relevant options are visible in the Manage Service Contracts app. 

Procedure

Step 1: Open configuration activity

As a configuration expert, you open the Manage Your Solution app and find the configuration activity Assign Date Rules to Settlement Period and Billing Date. You can also search for the configuration activity directly in your configuration environment. 

 

Step 2: Enable filter for date profile

Choose Configure to open the configuration activity. Select the date profile that you use for service contracts. In SAP pre-delivered configuration settings, CONT002 is the default date profile for service contracts. Tick the checkbox for Filter Active to enable the filter. By doing so, the filter is enabled for the cleaning up. 

Step 3: Assign date rules respectively

Select the date profile, CONT002 in our case, and double click the date rules from the dialog Structure. From this view, you can define which date rules are used for settlement period and which are used for billing date. Save all the settings you have made.

Step 4: Verify your settings in app

Now you can check the results in the Manage Service Contracts app. In the dropdown list for settlement rule, only the selected date rules relevant to settlements appear. In the dropdown list for billing date rule, only those date rules relevant to billing date appear.

 

Conclusion

In this blog, we explained how to clean up the in-app options for settlement rules by activating a filter to the date profile and then assigning date rules to respective purposes. With the assignment, you can get clearer lists of rule options in the Manage Service Contracts app. You can try this out in your own system and provide your feedback to us! Feel free to add a comment below or post a question.

entry.title: Re: Clear Salary outside HireDate and TerminationDate ran...
entry.content:
So I split the code into two and it works now

CONFIG.HIERARCHY.INCLUDE_MEMBERS_NOT_IN_HIERARCHY = [d/Account], [d/CostCenter], [d/Emp_Status], [d/Employee], [d/LegalEntity], [d/Location]
CONFIG.GENERATE_UNBOOKED_DATA = ON

MEMBERSET [d/Measures] = "Amount_LC"
MEMBERSET [d/Account] = "ACC_017"
MEMBERSET [d/DataSource] = "DS_PAYROLL"
MEMBERSET [d/Employee] = (BASEMEMBER([d/Employee].[h/EmpStatus], "ACTIVE", "TERMINATED", "TO_BE_HIRED", "INACTIVE"))

// Hire Date Proration
IF DATEDIFF([d/HireDate], [d/Date], "MONTH") < 0 THEN
    DATA([d/Account] = "ACC_017", [d/Measures] = "Amount_LC", [d/DataSource] = "DS_PAYROLL") = RESULTLOOKUP([d/Measures] = "Amount_LC") * 0
ELSE
    IF DATEDIFF([d/HireDate], [d/Date], "DAY") < 0 THEN
        DATA([d/Account] = "ACC_017", [d/Measures] = "Amount_LC", [d/DataSource] = "DS_PAYROLL") =
            (1 - ABS(DATEDIFF([d/HireDate], [d/Date], "DAY")) / DAYSINMONTH([d/Date])) * RESULTLOOKUP([d/Measures] = "Amount_LC")
    ELSE
        // Full month if hired before this month
        DATA([d/Measures] = "Amount_LC") = RESULTLOOKUP([d/Measures] = "Amount_LC")
    ENDIF
ENDIF

entry.title: How to Derive Profitability Segments in the Upload Customer Open Items app
entry.content:
Prerequisites

Before you can post to a profitability segment, ensure the following prerequisites are fulfilled:

  • You've activated profitability analysis for the relevant company code.

  • In the G/L account master data, you've defined the G/L account to be posted to as a cost element and assigned it to a field status group that allows posting to profitability segments.

Derivation-Related Fields

The upload template of the app contains a list of fields that can be used for deriving profitability segment data, including the following:

  • All the fields in the Additional Profitability Segment Fields section by SAP S/4HANA Cloud 2508


    Field Technical NameField Name
    PROVIDERCONTRACT

    Provider Contract (20)

    PROVIDERCONTRACTITEM

    Contract Item (6)

    CUSTOMER

    Customer (10)

    CUSTOMERGROUP

    Customer Group (2)

    INDUSTRY

    Industry (4)

    CUSTOMERCOUNTRYKEY

    Country/Region Key (3)

    SALESORGANIZATION

    Sales Organization (4)

    DISTRIBUTIONCHANNEL

    Distribution Channel (2)

    DIVISION

    Division (2)

    PRFTBLTYSEGMENTWBSELEMENTEXTID

    WBS Element (24)

     Note

    The WBS Element (24) (WBSELEMENT) in the G/L Account Items section and the WBS Element (24) (PRFTBLTYSEGMENTWBSELEMENTEXTID) in the Additional Profitability Segment Fields section are used for different purposes.

    If you want to post revenues to a WBS element, enter the WBS element only in the G/L Account Items section and ensure that it is a billing element. If you want to use a WBS element for profitability segment derivation, enter the WBS element only in the Additional Profitability Segment Fields section. This WBS element can either be a billing element or a non-billing element.

    BILLINGDOCUMENTTYPE

    Billing Type (4)

     

  • The following fields in the G/L Account Items section by SAP S/4HANA Cloud 2508:

    Field Technical NameField NameField Technical NameField Name
    COSTCENTER

    Cost Center (10)

    		FUNCTIONALAREA

    Functional Area (16)

    PROFITCENTER

    Profit Center (10)

    		SALESORDER

    Sales Document (10)

    PARTNERPROFITCENTER

    Partner Profit Center (10)

    		SALESORDERITEM

    Sales Document Item (6)

    INTERNALORDER

    Internal Order (12)

    		PLANT

    Plant (4)

    REPORTINGSEGMENT

    Reporting Segment (10)

    		SERVICEDOCUMENTTYPE

    Service Document Type (4)

    CONTROLLINGAREA

    Controlling Area (4)

    		SERVICEDOCID

    Service Document (10)

    MATERIALMaterial (40)SERVICEDOCITEMID

    Service Document Item (6)

     

Derivation Options

Once an open item that meets the above prerequisites is uploaded to the app, you can navigate to the G/L account item details page, where you can see a Profitability Segment field in the Account Assignment section and a corresponding Additional Profitability Segment Fields section. Depending on your settings and inputs, a profitability segment can either be derived automatically during posting or be manually derived and assigned before posting.

Auto-Derivation During Posting

To enable auto-derivation of profitability segment, you have two options:
  • Option 1
You can enter data in the Additional Profitability Segment Fields section, and post the open item directly. During the posting, a profitability segment is determined automatically based on the specified field values.
   
Example
You want to post an open customer invoice of EUR 100 to G/L account 41000400. In the master record, this G/L account has the type Primary Costs or Revenue and is assigned to a field status group that allows posting to profitability segments. You create an entry for this open item in the template and enter the following derivation-related fields:

SectionFieldField Value
G/L Account ItemsProfit Center (10)YB600
Additional Profitability Segment FieldsDistribution Channel (2)40
 

Once this open item is uploaded to the app, you can post it directly. During posting, the system automatically derives a profitability segment based on the specified profit center and distribution channel. When you open the posted journal entry in the Manage Journal Entries app, you see a profitability segment is assigned to the corresponding G/L line item.

 

  • Option 2

Alternatively, you can make the following configuration settings and maintain derivation-related fields as needed:

In your configuration environment, use the search function to open the activity Manage Default Account Assignments (ID: 102639). In this activity, find your G/L account, choose the checkbox of Profitability Segment for this G/L account, and save your settings. 

 
In this way, when you post the open item, a profitability segment is determined automatically.
Example

Let's have a look at two examples:

  • Example 1: Checkbox of profitability segment selected

    You want to post an open customer invoice of EUR 100 to G/L account 41000400. In the configuration activity, you selected the checkbox of profitability segment for this account. In this case, when the open item is posted directly, a profitability segment is derived automatically during posting.

  • Example 2: Checkbox of profitability segment selected and derivation-related fields maintained in both the configuration activity and the template
    You want to post an open customer invoice of EUR 100 to G/L account 41000400. In the configuration activity, you selected the checkbox of profitability segment for this account and enter a profit center and cost center as below:

    Field in the Configuration Activity
    		Field Value
    Profit CenterY1040
    Cost Center10100031
     
    At the same time, you enter some derivation-related fields in the template.

    SectionFieldField Value
    G/L Account ItemsProfit Center (10)YB600
     Cost Center (10)10101101
    Additional Profitability Segment FieldsCustomer (10)10100001
     Customer Group (10)02
     Industry (4)02
     

    Here, the values for profit center and cost center differ from those in the configuration activity. In this case, for the same fields, the values entered in the template has a higher priority. That is, when this open item is posted directly, profit center YB600 and cost center 10101101, together with the above additional fields, are considered for profitability segment derivation.

Manual Derivation and Assignment

You can also manually derive and assign a profitability segment within the app before posting an open item. The manually assigned profitability segment will then be used during posting.

 

To make the manual assignment, you switch to edit mode and choose the Assign Profitability Segment button in the Profitability Segment field. Once you choose this button, an assignment screen (Assignment to a Profitability Segment) pops up. This screen is where you can manually specify profitability-related fields and transfer your post from Financial Accounting to a profitability segment in Profitability Analysis.

  • If you‚Äôve entered derivation-related fields, these field values are written to the corresponding fields in the assignment screen. You can then choose the Derive button to derive other related profitability characteristics from the existing data.

  • If no derivation-related fields have been maintained, you can enter data as needed in the assignment screen and then choose Derive.

Once you finish the derivation and close this assignment screen, the Profitability Segment field is filled with the Assigned value. During posting, this manually assigned profitability segment is to be used.
 
Example
You want to post an open customer invoice of EUR 100 to G/L account 41000400. You create an entry for this open item in the template and maintain the following derivation-related fields:

SectionField Field Value
G/L Account ItemsProfit Center (10)YB600
Additional Profitability Segment FieldsCustomer (10)10100004
 Distribution Channel (2)40
 
After this open item is uploaded to the app, you navigate to the G/L item details page. In edit mode, you choose the Assign Profitability Segment button. In the pop-up screen, the Profit Center, Customer, and Distribution Channel fields are populated with values you specified, and once you choose Derive, other related profitability segment characteristics such as country/region key and ship-to party are derived. After you close this pop-up, the Profitability Segment field in the Account Assignment section has the Assigned value. The animated GIF below (English only) shows how this looks:
